recount3 quick start guide

Leonardo Collado-Torres

Lieber Institute for Brain Development, Johns Hopkins Medical Campus
lcolladotor@gmail.com

30 September 2020

Source: vignettes/recount3-quickstart.Rmd
recount3-quickstart.Rmd

Overview

The recount3 R/Bioconductor package is part of the recount3 project and is the latest iteration of the ReCount family of projects that provide access to uniformly-processed RNA sequencing datasets. The main documentation website for all the recount3-related projects is available at recount.bio. Please check that website for more information about how this R/Bioconductor package and other tools are related to each other.

R packages

To clarify the relationship between the R/Bioconductor packages and the phases of ReCount please check the table below:

Year Phase Main references R/Bioconductor
2011 ReCount DOI: 10.1186/1471-2105-12-449 none
2017 recount2 DOI: 10.1038/nbt.3838 10.12688/f1000research.12223.1 recount
2020 recount3 DOI: TODO recount3

Teams involved

The ReCount family involves the following teams:

  • Ben Langmead’s lab at JHU Computer Science
  • Kasper Daniel Hansen’s lab at JHBSPH Biostatistics Department
  • Leonardo Collado-Torres and Andrew E. Jaffe from LIBD
  • Abhinav Nellore’s lab at OHSU
  • Jeff Leek’s lab at JHBSPH Biostatistics Deparment
  • Data hosted by SciServer from IDIES at JHU

Basics

Install recount3

R is an open-source statistical environment which can be easily modified to enhance its functionality via packages. recount3 is a R package available via the Bioconductor repository for packages. R can be installed on any operating system from CRAN after which you can install recount3 by using the following commands in your R session:

if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE)) {
      install.packages("BiocManager")
  }

BiocManager::install("recount3")

## Check that you have a valid Bioconductor installation
BiocManager::valid()

You can install the development version from GitHub with:

BiocManager::install("LieberInstitute/recount3")

Required knowledge

recount3 is based on many other packages and in particular in those that have implemented the infrastructure needed for dealing with RNA-seq data. A recount3 user will benefit from being familiar with SummarizedExperiment to understand the objects recount3 generates. It might also prove to be highly beneficial to check the

  • DESeq2 and limma packages for performing differential expression analysis with the RangedSummarizedExperiment objects,
  • DEFormats package for switching the objects to those used by other differential expression packages such as edgeR,
  • derfinder package for performing annotation-agnostic differential expression analysis.

If you are asking yourself the question “Where do I start using Bioconductor?” you might be interested in this blog post.

Asking for help

As package developers, we try to explain clearly how to use our packages and in which order to use the functions. But R and Bioconductor have a steep learning curve so it is critical to learn where to ask for help. The blog post quoted above mentions some but we would like to highlight the Bioconductor support site as the main resource for getting help: remember to use the recount3 tag and check the older posts. Other alternatives are available such as creating GitHub issues and tweeting. However, please note that if you want to receive help you should adhere to the posting guidelines. It is particularly critical that you provide a small reproducible example and your session information so package developers can track down the source of the error.

Citing recount3

We hope that recount3 will be useful for your research. Please use the following information to cite the package and the overall approach. Thank you!

## Citation info
citation("recount3")

Quick start to using to recount3

After installing recount3 (Wilks, Collado-Torres, Zheng, Jaffe, et al., 2020), we need to load the package, which will automatically load the required dependencies.

## Load recount3 R package
library("recount3")

If you have identified a study of interest and want to access the gene level expression data, use create_rse() as shown below. create_rse() has arguments that will allow you to specify the annotation of interest for the given organism, and whether you want to download gene, exon or exon-exon junction expression data.

## Find all available human projects
human_projects <- available_projects()
#> using temporary cache /tmp/Rtmpi3MEEi/BiocFileCache
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:07 caching file sra.recount_project.MD.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/sra.recount_project.MD.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:07 caching file gtex.recount_project.MD.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/gtex/metadata/gtex.recount_project.MD.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:08 caching file tcga.recount_project.MD.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/tcga/metadata/tcga.recount_project.MD.gz'

## Find the project you are interested in,
## here we use SRP009615 as an example
proj_info <- subset(
    human_projects,
    project == "SRP009615" & project_type == "data_sources"
)

## Create a RangedSummarizedExperiment (RSE) object at the gene level
rse_gene_SRP009615 <- create_rse(proj_info)
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:12 downloading and reading the metadata.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:12 caching file sra.sra.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.sra.SRP009615.MD.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:12 caching file sra.recount_project.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.recount_project.SRP009615.MD.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:12 caching file sra.recount_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.recount_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:13 caching file sra.recount_seq_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.recount_seq_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:13 caching file sra.recount_pred.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.recount_pred.SRP009615.MD.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:13 downloading and reading the feature information.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:13 caching file human.gene_sums.G026.gtf.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/annotations/gene_sums/human.gene_sums.G026.gtf.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:15 downloading and reading the counts: 12 samples across 63856 features.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:15 caching file sra.gene_sums.SRP009615.G026.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/gene_sums/15/SRP009615/sra.gene_sums.SRP009615.G026.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:15 construcing the RangedSummarizedExperiment (rse) object.

## Explore that RSE object
rse_gene_SRP009615
#> class: RangedSummarizedExperiment 
#> dim: 63856 12 
#> metadata(8): time_created recount3_version ... annotation recount3_url
#> assays(1): raw_counts
#> rownames(63856): ENSG00000278704.1 ENSG00000277400.1 ...
#>   ENSG00000182484.15_PAR_Y ENSG00000227159.8_PAR_Y
#> rowData names(10): source type ... havana_gene tag
#> colnames(12): SRR387777 SRR387778 ... SRR389077 SRR389078
#> colData names(173): rail_id external_id ... recount_pred.pred.type
#>   BigWigURL

## You can also interactively choose your study of interest
if (interactive()) {
    ## Note that you can interactively explore the available projects
    proj_info_interactive <- interactiveDisplayBase::display(human_projects)

    ## Select a single row, then hit "send". The following code checks this.
    stopifnot(nrow(proj_info_interactive) == 1)

    ## This is similar to using the following code to explore all of
    ## ExperimentHub, choosing one recount3 entry, then hitting "send"
    # eh2 <- AnnotationHub::display(ExperimentHub::ExperimentHub())
    # proj_info_interactive <- eh2[[1]]

    ## Then create the RSE object
    rse_gene_interactive <- create_rse(proj_info_interactive)
}

## TODO scale_counts

recount3 also supports accessing the BigWig raw coverage files as well as specific study or compilation sample metadata. Please continue to the users guide for more detailed information.

Users guide

recount3 (Wilks, Collado-Torres, Zheng, Jaffe, et al., 2020) provides an interface for downloading the recount3 raw files and building Bioconductor-friendly R objects (Huber, Carey, Gentleman, Anders, et al., 2015; Morgan, Obenchain, Hester, and Pagès, 2019) that can be used with many downstream packages. To achieve this, the raw data is organized by study from a specific data source. That same study can be a part of one or more compilations, which is a manually curated set of studies with compilation-specific sample metadata (see the Data source vs collection for details). To get started with recount3, you will need to identify the ID for the study of interest from either human or mouse for a particular annotation of interest. Once you have identified study, data source or compilation, and annotation, recount3 can be used to build a RangedSummarizedExperiment object (Morgan, Obenchain, Hester, and Pagès, 2019) for either gene, exon or exon-exon junction expression feature data. For more advanced use cases, recount3 provides access to the coverage BigWig files that can be quantified for custom set of genomic regions using megadepth. Furthermore, snapcount allows fast-queries for custom exon-exon junctions and other custom input.

Find a study

In order to access data from recount3, the first step is to identify a project that you are interested in working with. Most of the project IDs are the ones you can find on the Sequence Read Archive (SRA). For example, SRP009615 which we use in the examples in this vignette.The exceptions are the Genotype-Expression and The Cancer Genome Atlas human studies, commonly known as GTEx and TCGA. Both GTEx and TCGA are available in recount3 by tissue.

Through available_projects()

While you can use external websites to find a study of interest, you can also use available_projects() to list the projects that are available in recount3 as shown below. This will return a data.frame() object that lists the unique project IDs.

human_projects <- available_projects()
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:16 caching file sra.recount_project.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:16 caching file gtex.recount_project.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:16 caching file tcga.recount_project.MD.gz.
dim(human_projects)
#> [1] 8742    5
head(human_projects)
#>       project organism file_source     project_home project_type
#> 1   SRP107565    human         sra data_sources/sra data_sources
#> 217 SRP149665    human         sra data_sources/sra data_sources
#> 221 SRP017465    human         sra data_sources/sra data_sources
#> 244 SRP119165    human         sra data_sources/sra data_sources
#> 250 SRP133965    human         sra data_sources/sra data_sources
#> 262 SRP096765    human         sra data_sources/sra data_sources

## Select a study of interest
project_info <- subset(
    human_projects,
    project == "SRP009615" & project_type == "data_sources"
)
project_info
#>         project organism file_source     project_home project_type
#> 65312 SRP009615    human         sra data_sources/sra data_sources

Let’s say that you are interested in the GTEx projects, you could then filter by file_source. We’ll focus only on those entries that from a data source, and not from a collection for now.

subset(human_projects, file_source == "gtex" & project_type == "data_sources")
#>                project organism file_source      project_home project_type
#> 316450  ADIPOSE_TISSUE    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316451          MUSCLE    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316452    BLOOD_VESSEL    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316454           HEART    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316456           OVARY    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316457          UTERUS    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316458          VAGINA    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316459          BREAST    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316460            SKIN    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316461  SALIVARY_GLAND    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316462           BRAIN    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316463   ADRENAL_GLAND    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316464         THYROID    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316465            LUNG    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316466          SPLEEN    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316467        PANCREAS    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316468       ESOPHAGUS    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316471         STOMACH    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316474           COLON    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316475 SMALL_INTESTINE    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316477        PROSTATE    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources

#> 316482           NERVE    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 316498       PITUITARY    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources

#> 329381    CERVIX_UTERI    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 329576  FALLOPIAN_TUBE    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 329668         BLADDER    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 331476        STUDY_NA    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources
#> 335460     BONE_MARROW    human        gtex data_sources/gtex data_sources

Note that one of the projects for GTEx is STUDY_NA, that’s because in recount3 we processed all GTEx samples, including some that had no tissue assigned and were not used by the GTEx consortium.

If you prefer to view the list of available studies interactively, you can do so with interactiveDisplayBase as shown below. You’ll want to assign the output of interactiveDisplayBase::display() to an object so you can save your selections and use them later. By doing so, you’ll be able to select a study of interest, and save the information for later use after you hit the “send” button.

if (interactive()) {
    ## Interactively browse the human projects, select one, then hit send
    selected_study <- interactiveDisplayBase::display(human_projects)
}

Through recount3_hub()

Alternatively, you can use ExperimentHub to search all of the available studies, filter the ones that have a recount3 tag, and then use that information with this package to retrieve the data. Just like with our approach using interactiveDisplayBase::display() and available_projects(), you can also interactively explore the data from r ExperimentHub.

## Retrieve the experiments in ExperimentHub
eh <- ExperimentHub::ExperimentHub()
#> snapshotDate(): 2020-09-24

if (interactive()) {
    ## Search for the recount3 tag, find a study of interest, select it, then
    ## hit send
    eh2 <- AnnotationHub::display(ExperimentHub::ExperimentHub())

    ## Retrieve the study data from ExperimentHub
    selected_study_eh <- eh2[[1]]
}

The process of retrieving the project information from ExperimentHub is simplified in recount3_hub() for situations where you know the project ID already as shown for SRP009615.

project_info <- recount3_hub("SRP009615")
#> snapshotDate(): 2020-09-24
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:22 the project SRP009615 was not found on ExperimentHub.
#> Using a backup mechanism powered by recount3::available_projects().
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:22 caching file sra.recount_project.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:23 caching file gtex.recount_project.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:23 caching file tcga.recount_project.MD.gz.

Ultimately, we need three pieces of information in order to download a specific dataset from recount3. Those are:

  • project: the project ID,
  • organism: either human or mouse,
  • project_home: where the data lives which varies between data sources and collections.
project_info
#>     project organism     project_home
#> 1 SRP009615    human data_sources/sra

Available annotations

Now that we have identified our project of interest, the next step is to choose an annotation that we want to work with. The annotation files available depend on the organism. To facilitate finding the specific names we use in recount3, we have provided the function annotation_options().

annotation_options("human")
#> [1] "gencode_v26" "gencode_v29" "fantom6_cat" "refseq"      "ercc"       
#> [6] "sirv"
annotation_options("mouse")
#> [1] "gencode_v23"

The main sources are:

  • GENCODE project
  • RefSeq: NCBI Reference Sequence Database
  • FANTOM6_CAT is described at DOI 10.1101/gr.254656.119
  • ERCC: External RNA Controls Consortium 1, commercially available from ThermoFisher Scientific
  • SIRV 2, commercially available from Lexogen

In recount3 we have provided multiple annotations, which is different from recount (recount2 R/Bioconductor package) where all files were computed using GENCODE version 25. However, in both, you might be interested in quantifying your annotation of interest, as described further below in the BigWig files section.

Build a RSE

Once you have chosen an annotation and a project, you can now build a RangedSummarizedExperiment object (Huber, Carey, Gentleman, Anders, et al., 2015; Morgan, Obenchain, Hester, and Pagès, 2019). To do so, we recommend using the create_rse() function as shown below for GENCODE v26 (the default annotation for human files). create_rse() internally uses several other recount3 functions for locating the necessary raw files, downloading them, reading them, and building the RangedSummarizedExperiment (RSE) object. create_rse() shows several status message updates that you can silence with suppressMessages(create_rse()) if you want to.

## Create a RSE object at the gene level
rse_gene_SRP009615 <- create_rse(project_info)
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:26 downloading and reading the metadata.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:26 caching file sra.sra.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:26 caching file sra.recount_project.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:27 caching file sra.recount_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:27 caching file sra.recount_seq_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:27 caching file sra.recount_pred.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:27 downloading and reading the feature information.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:27 caching file human.gene_sums.G026.gtf.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:28 downloading and reading the counts: 12 samples across 63856 features.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:28 caching file sra.gene_sums.SRP009615.G026.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:28 construcing the RangedSummarizedExperiment (rse) object.

## Explore the resulting RSE gene object
rse_gene_SRP009615
#> class: RangedSummarizedExperiment 
#> dim: 63856 12 
#> metadata(8): time_created recount3_version ... annotation recount3_url
#> assays(1): raw_counts
#> rownames(63856): ENSG00000278704.1 ENSG00000277400.1 ...
#>   ENSG00000182484.15_PAR_Y ENSG00000227159.8_PAR_Y
#> rowData names(10): source type ... havana_gene tag
#> colnames(12): SRR387777 SRR387778 ... SRR389077 SRR389078
#> colData names(173): rail_id external_id ... recount_pred.pred.type
#>   BigWigURL

Explore the RSE

Because the RSE object is created at run-time in recount3, unlike the static files provided by recount for recount2, create_rse() stores information about how this RSE object was made under metadata(). This information is useful in case you share the RSE object and someone else wants to be able to re-make the object with the latest data 3.

## Information about how this RSE object was made
metadata(rse_gene_SRP009615)
#> $time_created
#> [1] "2020-09-30 02:09:28 UTC"
#> 
#> $recount3_version
#>           package ondiskversion loadedversion
#> recount3 recount3        0.99.0        0.99.0
#>                                                 path
#> recount3 /usr/local/lib/R/host-site-library/recount3
#>                                           loadedpath attached is_base
#> recount3 /usr/local/lib/R/host-site-library/recount3     TRUE   FALSE
#>                date       source md5ok                            library
#> recount3 2020-09-30 Bioconductor    NA /usr/local/lib/R/host-site-library
#> 
#> $project
#> [1] "SRP009615"
#> 
#> $project_home
#> [1] "data_sources/sra"
#> 
#> $type
#> [1] "gene"
#> 
#> $organism
#> [1] "human"
#> 
#> $annotation
#> [1] "gencode_v26"
#> 
#> $recount3_url
#> [1] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data"

The SRP009615 study was composed of 12 samples, for which we have 63,856 genes in GENCODE v26. The annotation-specific information is available through rowRanges() as shown below with the gene_id column used to identify genes in each of the annotations 4.

## Number of genes by number of samples
dim(rse_gene_SRP009615)
#> [1] 63856    12

## Information about the genes
rowRanges(rse_gene_SRP009615)

#>          ENSG00000277400.1                 <NA>        <NA>
#>          ENSG00000274847.1                 <NA>        <NA>
#>          ENSG00000277428.1                 <NA>        <NA>
#>          ENSG00000276256.1                 <NA>        <NA>
#>                        ...                  ...         ...
#>   ENSG00000124334.17_PAR_Y OTTHUMG00000022720.1         PAR
#>   ENSG00000185203.12_PAR_Y OTTHUMG00000022676.3         PAR
#>    ENSG00000270726.6_PAR_Y OTTHUMG00000184987.2         PAR
#>   ENSG00000182484.15_PAR_Y OTTHUMG00000022677.5         PAR
#>    ENSG00000227159.8_PAR_Y OTTHUMG00000022678.1         PAR
#>   -------
#>   seqinfo: 374 sequences from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths

Sample metadata

The sample metadata provided in recount3 is much more extensive than the one in recount for the recount2 project because it’s includes for quality control metrics, predictions, and information used internally by recount3 functions such as create_rse(). All individual metadata tables include the columns rail_id, external_id and study which are used for merging the different tables. Finally, **BigWigUrl* provides the URL for the BigWig file for the given sample.

## Sample metadata
recount3_cols <- colnames(colData(rse_gene_SRP009615))

## How many are there?
length(recount3_cols)
#> [1] 173

## View the first few ones
head(recount3_cols)
#> [1] "rail_id"            "external_id"        "study"             
#> [4] "sra.sample_acc.x"   "sra.experiment_acc" "sra.submission_acc"

## Group them by source
recount3_cols_groups <- table(gsub("\\..*", "", recount3_cols))

## Common sources and number of columns per source
recount3_cols_groups[recount3_cols_groups > 1]
#> 
#>    recount_pred recount_project      recount_qc  recount_seq_qc             sra 
#>               5               5             109              12              38

## Unique columns
recount3_cols_groups[recount3_cols_groups == 1]
#> 
#>   BigWigURL external_id     rail_id       study 
#>           1           1           1           1

## Explore them all
if (interactive()) {
    recount3_cols
}

Counts

The counts in recount3 are raw base-pair coverage counts, similar to those in recount. To further understand them, check the recountWorkflow DOI 10.12688/f1000research.12223.1. To highlight that these arw raw base-pair coverage counts, they are stored in the “raw_counts” assay

assayNames(rse_gene_SRP009615)
#> [1] "raw_counts"

Using TODO you can scale the counts and assign them to the “counts” slot to use them in downstream packages such as DESeq2 and limma.

## TODO

Advanced features

recount3 provides an interface to raw files that go beyond gene counts, as well as other features you might be interested in.

Exon

First, you might want to study expression at the exon expression level instead of gene. To do so, use the type argument in create_rse() as shown below.

## Create a RSE object at the exon level
rse_exon_SRP009615 <- create_rse(
    proj_info,
    type = "exon"
)
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:29 downloading and reading the metadata.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:29 caching file sra.sra.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:29 caching file sra.recount_project.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:29 caching file sra.recount_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:29 caching file sra.recount_seq_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:30 caching file sra.recount_pred.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:30 downloading and reading the feature information.
#> 2020-09-30 02:09:30 caching file human.exon_sums.G026.gtf.gz.

Each exon is shown in this output, so, you might have to filter the exons of interest. Unlike in recount2, these are actual exons and not disjoint exons 5.

## Exon ids are repeated because a given exon can be part of
## more than one transcript
length(unique(rowRanges(rse_exon_SRP009615)$exon_id))
#> [1] 742049

Because there are many more exons than genes, this type of analysis uses more computational resources. Thus, for some large projects you might need to use a high performance computing environment. To help you proceed with caution, create_rse() shows how many features and samples it’s trying to access. So if you get an out of memory error, you’ll know why that happened.

## Check how much memory the gene and exon RSE objects use
pryr::object_size(rse_gene_SRP009615)
#> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'pryr':
#>   method      from
#>   print.bytes Rcpp
#> 21.7 MB
pryr::object_size(rse_exon_SRP009615)
#> 466 MB

Exon-exon junctions

In recount3 we have also provided the option to create RSE files for exon-exon junctions. Unlike the gene/exon RSE files, only the junctions present in a given project are included in the files, so you’ll have to be more careful when merging exon-exon junction RSE files. Furthermore, these are actual read counts and not raw base-pair counts. Given the sparsity of the data, the counts are provided using a sparse matrix object from Matrix. Thus exon-exon junction files can be less memory demanding than the exon RSE files.

## Create a RSE object at the exon-exon junction level
rse_jxn_SRP009615 <- create_rse(
    proj_info,
    type = "jxn"
)
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:00 downloading and reading the metadata.
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:00 caching file sra.sra.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:01 caching file sra.recount_project.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:01 caching file sra.recount_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:01 caching file sra.recount_seq_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:01 caching file sra.recount_pred.SRP009615.MD.gz.
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:02 downloading and reading the feature information.
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:02 caching file sra.junctions.SRP009615.ALL.RR.gz.
#> adding rname 'http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/junctions/15/SRP009615/sra.junctions.SRP009615.ALL.RR.gz'
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:04 downloading and reading the counts: 12 samples across 281448 features.
#> 2020-09-30 02:10:04 caching file sra.junctions.SRP009615.ALL.MM.gz.

Local files

recount3 depends on BiocFileCache (Shepherd and Morgan, 2020) for organizing the raw files and caching them, such that if you use the same file more than once, you only have to download it once. BiocFileCache will automatically update the file if it detects that the file has changed in the source

If you want to inspect which files you have downloaded or even delete them, them you’ll want to use BiocFileCache functions such as BiocFileCache::bfcinfo() and BiocFileCache::bfcremove() as illustrated below.

library("BiocFileCache")
#> Loading required package: dbplyr

## Set up your cache the same way you used the functions
bfc <- BiocFileCache()

## Locate all files
bfc_files <- bfcinfo()

## Find files from recount3
bfc_recount3 <- grep("recount3", bfc_files[["fpath"]])

## List the original URLs for the data
bfc_files[["fpath"]][bfc_recount3]
#>  [1] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/sra.recount_project.MD.gz"                       
#>  [2] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/gtex/metadata/gtex.recount_project.MD.gz"                     
#>  [3] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/tcga/metadata/tcga.recount_project.MD.gz"                     
#>  [4] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.sra.SRP009615.MD.gz"            
#>  [5] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.recount_project.SRP009615.MD.gz"
#>  [6] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.recount_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz"     
#>  [7] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.recount_seq_qc.SRP009615.MD.gz" 
#>  [8] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/metadata/15/SRP009615/sra.recount_pred.SRP009615.MD.gz"   
#>  [9] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/annotations/gene_sums/human.gene_sums.G026.gtf.gz"                         
#> [10] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/gene_sums/15/SRP009615/sra.gene_sums.SRP009615.G026.gz"   
#> [11] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/annotations/exon_sums/human.exon_sums.G026.gtf.gz"                         
#> [12] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/exon_sums/15/SRP009615/sra.exon_sums.SRP009615.G026.gz"   
#> [13] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/junctions/15/SRP009615/sra.junctions.SRP009615.ALL.RR.gz" 
#> [14] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/junctions/15/SRP009615/sra.junctions.SRP009615.ALL.MM.gz" 
#> [15] "http://idies.jhu.edu/recount3/data/human/data_sources/sra/junctions/15/SRP009615/sra.junctions.SRP009615.ALL.ID.gz"

## You can remove the recount3 files from your cache if you want using bfcremove
if (interactive()) {
    bfcremove(bfc, rids = bfc_files[["rid"]][bfc_recount3])

    ## Verify that the recount3 files have been deleted
    bfcinfo()
}

BigWig files

Internally we used GenomicFeatures::exonicParts() when processing all annotations in recount3 instead of GenomicRanges::disjoin() that was used in recount2. We then re-assembled the counts for each exon/gene to create the count files provided in recount3. However, you might want to exclude the overlapping exonic parts from the counts. If that’s the case or if you are interested in specific regions of the hg38/mm10 genomes, you might want to access the coverage BigWig files.

## BigWig file names
## The full URL is stored in BigWigUrl
basename(head(rse_gene_SRP009615$BigWigURL))
#> [1] "sra.base_sums.SRP009615_SRR387777.ALL.bw"
#> [2] "sra.base_sums.SRP009615_SRR387778.ALL.bw"
#> [3] "sra.base_sums.SRP009615_SRR387779.ALL.bw"
#> [4] "sra.base_sums.SRP009615_SRR387780.ALL.bw"
#> [5] "sra.base_sums.SRP009615_SRR389079.ALL.bw"
#> [6] "sra.base_sums.SRP009615_SRR389080.ALL.bw"

These BigWig files can be accessed using rtracklayer::import.bw() from R, or other tools such as bwtool that we’ve used in the past 6. Using them, you can compute a coverage matrix for a given set of regions.

One new software we developed is megadepth for which we have provided an R/Bioconductor package interface. megadepth is faster at accessing BigWig files and is the software we used internally for generating the recount3 data. megadepth provides convenient to use functions for quantifying a set of regions, which might be of interest for co-expression analyses where double counting exonic parts can be problematic.

You can also use derfinder and derfinderPlot if you are interested in visualizing the base-pair coverage data for a specific region using these BigWig coverage files.

Your own mirror

recount3 functions such as create_rse() have a recount3_url argument that can be changed to point to a mirror or to a path in your computing system. This argument enables using recount3 with data stored in other locations, or even generated using the same processing pipeline that was used for recount3 but for your own/private data.

The main documentation website documents how the raw files should be organized in your mirror or for your own data. You can inspect the structure of the data by checking the internals of file_locate_url() and file_locate_url_annotation(). Both functions can be used to get the full list of URLs. In addition, for a given mirror, available_projects() will show the local data sources and collections. Finally, file_retrieve() won’t cache the data if it detects that the data already exists in the local disk.

In particular, this functionality can be useful if you want to access the data at IDIES using SciServer Compute.

Other related tools

The ReCount team has worked on several software solutions and projects that complement each other and enable you to re-use public RNA-seq data. Another Bioconductor package that you might be highly interested in is snapcount, which allows you to use the Snaptron web services. In particular, snapcount is best for queries over a particular subset of genes or intervals across all or most of the samples in recount2/Snaptron.

We remind you that the main documentation website for all the recount3-related projects is available at recount.bio. Please check that website for more information about how this R/Bioconductor package and other tools are related to each other.

Thank you!

P.S. An alternative version of this vignette is available that was made using pkgdown.

The recount3 package (Collado-Torres, 2020) was made possible thanks to:

  • R (R Core Team, 2020)

  • XML (Temple Lang, 2020)

## Create the vignette
library("rmarkdown")
system.time(render("recount3-quickstart.Rmd", "BiocStyle::html_document"))

## Extract the R code
library("knitr")
knit("recount3-quickstart.Rmd", tangle = TRUE)

## Clean up
file.remove("quickstartRef.bib")
